This week, global markets appeared relatively stable, but beneath the quiet closing prices, two powerful narratives were in a constant tug-of-war: the controversy surrounding Federal Reserve independence and the rising geopolitical risk premiums stemming from the situation in Iran.

U.S.: Powell’s Legal Investigation and the “Soft Landing” Narrative

The first major event this week involved Fed Chair Jerome Powell, who faced a Justice Department investigation regarding testimony related to the renovation of the Federal Reserve building. Investors quickly looked past the legal gossip to the deeper systemic risk: Is this investigation a form of political pressure from the Trump administration to force faster rate cuts?

This perceived threat to Fed independence initially triggered a classic trade—Gold strengthened, the Dollar weakened, and Treasuries were sold off. However, the momentum shifted on Friday when President Trump signaled that National Economic Council Director Kevin Hassett would remain in the White House. This move implied that Hassett—a noted hawk—would likely not be the next Fed Chair. Consequently, the market dialed back expectations for aggressive future rate cuts, causing the Dollar to rebound and Gold to face profit-taking.

Despite these macro fluctuations, the equity market remained resilient. TSMC’s strong Q4 earnings and ambitious expansion plans continued to fuel the AI investment fever, providing a solid floor for the semiconductor sector. Furthermore, data showing cooling inflation alongside economic resilience bolstered the “soft landing” narrative. This environment favored mid-and-small-cap stocks over large-cap growth giants, resulting in a noticeable sector rotation while major indices remained near their highs.

Europe: Capital Inflows and Regional Strength

European markets largely followed the U.S. rhythm, though performance was underpinned by improving local macro data. European bonds benefited significantly from capital inflows seeking a haven from the Fed independence drama in the U.S. In the UK, better-than-expected economic performance boosted the stock market, though it left the Gilt market (UK bonds) relatively weak.

Japan: The “Sanae Takaichi Trade” Re-ignites

The primary focus in Japan remains the political landscape surrounding Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi. Reports this week show that Takaichi might dissolve the House of Representatives for a snap election as early as next week. The market logic is straightforward: if a re-election secures a stronger majority for the LDP, Takaichi will have a much smoother path to implementing her signature proactive fiscal expansion.

This anticipation triggered a familiar rally in Japanese equities, driven by policy imagination. The Yen initially weakened significantly before a slight recovery following “verbal interventions” from Japan’s Finance Minister. However, the prospect of a weaker Yen and fiscal expansion continues to put pressure on the Bank of Japan to accelerate rate hikes, pushing JGB yields higher across the curve.

Commodities: Iran Tensions

The ongoing civil unrest and escalating tensions in Iran, together, caused oil prices to jump early in the week. While President Trump released characteristically tough rhetoric toward Iran, the market remains uncertain whether this will lead to a substantive military escalation or simply serve as a deterrent for future negotiations. As a result, oil prices experienced a volatile week—spiking during periods of tension and retreating on signs of de-escalation—ultimately closing slightly higher than last week.

The gold has been pushed up by the doubt of Federal Reserve independence and Middle Eastern tensions. It hit the historical high and faced a strategic pullback as political signals shifted.

This created a dual impact: a long-term expectation of increased global oil supply (putting downward pressure on prices) and a massive potential opportunity for U.S. energy giants to enter the Venezuelan market. Consequently, the energy sector led the charge upward.
  • AI and Tech Momentum: Beyond geopolitics, the tech sector remained white-hot. Strong performance from TSMC and the excitement surrounding the CES exhibition continued to fuel AI investment enthusiasm.

The European markets largely mirrored the U.S. sentiment-driven rally. Stock market was propelled by the same optimism seen in the U.S., with energy and defense sectors outperforming. And the government bonds actually performed stronger than U.S. Treasuries, primarily supported by regional data showing a steady cooling of inflation.

Japan: Political Rumors and the Yen’s Decline

The Japanese market opened its first full trading week of the year by catching up to global volatility while contending with significant domestic political shifts.

Rumors surfaced on Friday suggesting that Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi, currently enjoying a high approval rating of around 70%, may dissolve the House of Representatives for a snap election as early as February. This prospect of political stabilization initially excited equity markets, with the Nikkei 225 jumping nearly 3% to reach fresh record highs.

However, the move is a double-edged sword: the market anticipates that a stronger mandate for Takaichi would pave the way for her “Sanaenomics” agenda of aggressive, proactive fiscal expansion. This alarm over fiscal sustainability triggered a sharp depreciation of the Yen, which in turn boosted export-oriented stocks but pushed Japanese Government Bond (JGB) yields to 27-year highs near 2.14% as investors worried about the inflationary impact and potential further rate hikes by the Bank of Japan.

Commodities: A Tug-of-War Between Risk and Supply

Oil price saw a “spike and fade” pattern. The geopolitical risk premium was eventually offset by the prospect of Venezuela’s reserves returning to the global market under U.S. influence.

Gold remained supported by the underlying geopolitical tension, though the broader “risk-on” mood in equities limited its upward momentum.

entry.title: What Happened to Silver This Year?
entry.content:
While mainstream investors were patting themselves on the back for a respectable 14% return on the S&P 500 in 2025, a quiet revolution was taking place in the commodities sector. Silver—often dismissed as “Gold’s little brother”—exploded by 170% within a single year, outperforming gold by more than double.

This was not a simple cyclical recovery. It was a “perfect storm” woven from structural shortages, geopolitical maneuvering, and high-leverage algorithmic warfare.

The “1:200” Shadow Game: How Leverage Built a Throne for Silver

The core mechanism behind silver’s insanity lies in a highly opaque market structure that expanded paper claims far beyond physical reality.

  • Physical-to-Paper Conversion: Speculators borrowed physical silver from miners, pledged it to banks for liquidity, and used that capital to go long on the market.
  • The Re-hypothecation Loop: Banks took those pledged certificates and lent them again to ETF issuers. This “multi-link” pledging resulted in a derivatives market that expanded silver’s exposure to more than 1:200 ratio against actual physical bars.
  • The Fatal Squeeze: When “Whales” demanded physical delivery, shorts found themselves in a vacuum. By October 2025, silver lease rates spiked to 30%, briefly hitting 100% in the London market as shorts scrambled to avoid default.

The Structural Deadlock: Supply and Demand Imbalance

The fundamental floor for this price surge is a supply-demand mismatch that has finally reached a breaking point.

Global silver has faced a supply deficit for five consecutive years.

Furthermore, silver’s industrial profile has changed as it is the most conductive metal on earth. In the AI era, it has become indispensable for high-performance chips and data center infrastructure while the solar industry’s shift to TOPCon cells has increased silver loading by up to 50% per unit.

Finally, a strategic revaluation has taken hold as the U.S. added silver to its critical minerals list, while China implemented export licensing in 2026, signaling the end of the era of cheap, abundant silver.

Geofinancial Drivers: India, Russia, and the JPMorgan Migration

The acceleration in late 2025 was catalyzed by deep geopolitical coupling and a major shift in institutional behavior. In October 2025, mysterious Indian buyers placed a delivery order for 1,000 tons in London, instantly draining New York’s available spot inventory and suggesting that silver was being used as a medium to help Russia convert “trapped” oil rupees into tangible bullion. This movement effectively tested a quasi-Silver Standard for cross-border settlements.

Simultaneously, JPMorgan, silver’s largest historical market maker, effectively flipped the table by moving their trading desk to Singapore to align with the Asian pivot. They engaged in aggressive physical take-delivery, shifting hundreds of tons from “eligible” to “locked” status and joining the squeeze they once managed.

2026 Outlook

As we exit 2025, silver hovers near the $80/oz mark. What’s next?

  • The “Ghost Week” Surge: During the liquidity vacuum between Christmas and New Year (Ghost Week), roughly 145,000 futures contracts were locked. With no sellers in sight, even minimal buying pressure triggered massive price gaps.
  • The Long-term Bull Case: Since gold reaches $4,500, based on gold-to-silver historical extreme ratio, 15:1, the theoretical target for silver could reach $300.
  • The Pullbacks Warning: Silver’s volatility is typically double that of gold. Expect technical pullbacks in early 2026 due to passive fund rebalancing (BCOM index adjustments) and potential hawkish pivots from the Fed.

  • Soft CB Consumer Confidence: The actual number is 89.1, lower than previous 92.9.

Thus, the market chose to focus on capital flows rather than macro shifts. Funds continue to rotate into the AI sector, reinforcing the trend where the winners of 2025 keep winning as the year closes.

Japan: Leader of The Global Bond Ripple

The ripple effect from the Bank of Japan (BOJ) continues to be felt across global fixed-income markets.

Following last week’s symbolic rate hike to 0.75%, the Yen surprisingly weakened rather than strengthened. This raised fears of imported inflation, putting pressure on the BOJ to tighten further in 2026. Combined with concerns over expanded fiscal budgets and increased bond supply, Japan’s 10-year yield surged past 2.1%, its highest since 1999.

While the “JGB Shock” initially dragged down U.S. and European bond prices, the U.S. Treasury market found support. A solid 7-year note auction proved that demand remains robust at these yield levels, allowing U.S. Treasuries to end the week slightly stronger despite the global pressure. And the European bonds recovered due to holiday-driven buying.

Europe: A Holiday Break

With most European markets open for only two and a half days due to the Christmas holidays, stocks saw a mild “Santa Rally” but on very thin volume, characterized more by sector rotation than broad directional moves.

  • Silver’s Industrial Edge: Silver outpaced gold this week. As a “dual-purpose” metal, it benefited both from the precious metals rally and its critical role in the AI infrastructure buildout (data centers) and green energy.

With a lower concentration of AI-sensitive tech giants, European equities outperformed U.S. indices this week, buoyed by improving regional economic outlooks and stabilizing inflation.

In a seemingly counterintuitive move, the Yen weakened against the Dollar after the hike. Governor Kazuo Ueda’s post-meeting press conference was characteristically vague regarding future hikes, leading the market to interpret his tone as “dovish.” Nikkei futures surged as a result.

Despite the Yen’s weakness, the hike confirmed higher long-term financing costs. Combined with concerns over Japan’s 2026 fiscal expansion and increased bond supply, the 10-year JGB yield broke through the 2.0% psychological barrier.

U.S. Market: Small-Cap Rally, Tech Slump, and a Steeper Curve

The details of the Fed’s decision released cautious signals, tempering expectations for an accelerating pace of future cuts:

  • Dot Plot: The Dot Plot indicated that officials forecast possibly only one additional rate cut in 2026, and the vote showed increasing division.
  • Hawkish Commentary: Post-meeting remarks from hawkish officials expressed caution regarding further easing.

These factors combined to cause short-term rates to fall while long-term rates rose, resulting in a steepening yield curve . Notably, this scenario of a rate cut alongside rising long-term yields is not unique to this week but is a major trend characterizing the entire Fed easing cycle.

While strengthening rate cut expectations should theoretically push entire bond yields curve down (prices up), the “Goldilocks” environment (no immediate recession risk) meant safe-haven demand was weak. Optimistic sentiment drove funds from the bond market to the stock market, causing upward shift of U.S. Treasury yield curve (price to fall).

The stock market showed conflicting trends this week:

  • Positive Drivers: The rate cut decision itself, along with the Fed’s plan to purchase short-term Treasuries as needed, boosted sentiment, leading to a global rally on Thursday.
  • Negative Concerns: Disappointing earnings guidance from tech giants like Broadcom and Oracle reignited market anxiety over the AI valuation bubble.

The combination of these two factors resulted in a fragmented U.S. market: small-cap stocks rallied on the rate cut impulse, while tech stocks were weighed down and declined.

Europe & Japan: Tightening vs. Easing Expectations

The Europe market trend was similar to the U.S., but European bond prices fell more sharply than U.S. Treasuries. One reason is the renewed market speculation that the European Central Bank (ECB) could potentially pivot to hiking rates in 2026, a more hawkish stance than the Fed’s cautious easing.

The Bank of Japan (BOJ) continued its public communication campaign, paving the way for a likely rate hike decision next week.

  • Hike Expectations Solidify: By Friday, nearly all institutional economists forecast the BOJ would hike rates to 0.75% next week. Authoritative financial media like Nikkei also reported that the hike was virtually confirmed .
  • JGB Yields Climb: The expected return to tightening pushed government bond yields higher. This effect, combined with market concerns over increased bond issuance due to an anticipated expansion of the 2026 fiscal budget, caused Japanese government bond (JGB) yields to continue rising (prices to fall).
  • Nikkei Gain: Japanese stocks closed slightly higher, primarily benefiting from the momentum of the U.S. rally following the Fed cut. The decline in U.S. stocks on Friday did not affect the Nikkei’s closing price due to the time zone difference.

Commodities: Silver Outperforms, Oil Drops Sharply

The rate cut reduced the opportunity cost of holding gold, pushing gold prices higher. Silver, a high leveraged commodity with way smaller market size, not only benefited from gold’s momentum but also from the logic that lower rates would stimulate the economy and boost industrial demand (for more details on how silver market plays, please see this note). Consequently, silver surged more sharply than gold this week.

Oil prices dropped sharply this week. The primary driver was the assessment by the International Energy Agency (IEA) and other bodies that the global oil market faces a significant supply surplus in 2026, which overshadowed short-term supply disruptions.

entry.title: The Global Monetary "Duet" and the New Order - Global Assets Amid Japan Hikes and US Cuts
entry.content:
The global financial market is currently witnessing a “duet” of monetary policy orchestrated by the two major economies, the U.S. and Japan: Japan is hiking the interest rate, while the Federal Reserve cut its interest rate by 25bps on Wednesday. This has triggered traditional fears of a global asset collapse and liquidity squeeze, especially considering Japan’s unexpected rate hike last July triggered a global stock market plunge (Nikkei fell 13% in a single day, Nasdaq dropped 3.4%).

From my point of view, the essence of this move is a meticulously orchestrated global liquidity expectation management, rather than a simple risk outbreak.

Global Liquidity Management: Unwinding Carry Trades with Fed Coordination

The Traditional Panic: Unwinding the Carry Trade

Traditional concerns stem from the massive size (estimated at $3–4 trillion) of the “Carry Trade” . For years, speculators borrowed the Japanese Yen at ultra-low rates (0.5%–1%) to purchase high-yield USD assets (such as 4% U.S. Treasuries or Nasdaq stocks).

If Japan were to hike rates abruptly due to domestic inflation (which reached 3%), these carry funds would rush back to Japan, draining liquidity from global capital markets and causing asset prices to crash.

Policy Essence: Coordinated Liquidity Management

Unlike the surprise hike last year, Japan’s current tightening is believed to be externally encouraged, possibly led by U.S. Treasury officials. The core logic is: The Fed is shifting toward releasing liquidity (ending QT, quantitative tightening, and starting the first round RMP, Researve Management Purchases). If both the U.S. and Japan simultaneously unleash massive liquidity, it could lead to short-term asset overheating and greater systemic financial risk.

Therefore, the Bank of Japan’s measured rate hike is essentially coordinating with the Fed to balance global monetary supply. This operation is designed to preemptively release risk and control liquidity expectations. Given the frequent policy signaling, the market has largely priced this in; while short-term volatility is inevitable, the probability of a major market collapse is considered low.

Dollar Hegemony’s Dilemma and China’s Structural Challenge

The Fed’s entry into a rate-cutting cycle signals a fundamental shift in the global financial landscape, closely linked to the U.S. dollar’s struggles and China’s rising influence.

The Dollar System’s Pivot: From Financial Warfare to Fiscal Survival

The U.S. dollar system is fundamentally a debt system, backed by U.S. Treasuries, which achieves periodic wealth harvesting through “tides” of expansion and contraction (liquidity cycles).

However, this harvesting model is becoming less effective as China has solidified its control over core global production capacity, particularly in high-end sectors like New Energy Vehicles, lithium batteries, and photovoltaic products. The Fed’s attempt to harvest via high-interest rate hikes failed to deliver the expected results and instead triggered a domestic debt crisis (U.S. national debt is now over $37 trillion) .

To resolve this “debt black hole,” the U.S. must execute a political and monetary pivot. The previous strategy of “Strong Dollar/Strong Fiscal Spending” is unsustainable and must transition to a “Weak Dollar/Weak Fiscal” model (Please see my previous blog for more details). This pivot involves Quantitative Easing (QE) and rate cuts to address systemic leverage and debt issues. This historical trend of a weak dollar cycle (anticipated from 2023 to 2030) typically resolves massive systemic leverage through currency devaluation.

China’s “Impossible Trinity” and Industrial Upgrade

In response to external liquidity changes, China’s domestic economy faces an “Impossible Trinity” (Trilemma) . China struggles to simultaneously achieve:

  1. High Welfare and High Wages: Workers enjoy comprehensive social security and a dignified income.
  2. Low Manufacturing Costs: Factories maintain a low-cost advantage to sustain global competitiveness (“World Factory”).
  3. Vibrant Domestic Consumption: A domestic market where people are willing and able to spend.

Forcing high labor standards would increase manufacturing costs, driving factories to lower-cost regions like Vietnam or India and undermining the “World Factory” foundation. Conversely, maintaining a low-cost advantage (low wages, poor social security) discourages consumer spending, stalling the domestic demand market.

The only viable path is industrial re-upgrading. By moving beyond low-value assembly to high-value sectors like chips and robotics, enterprises can afford higher wages while maintaining international competitiveness.

Additionally, the slow velocity of money also reflects weak consumer and investment sentiment, with capital “sleeping” in banks. The Fed’s entry into a cutting cycle provides room for the PBoC to ease further. Lower rates and inflation expectations are needed to incentivize the public to consume and invest, thereby accelerating capital circulation and revitalizing the economy.

Commodity Logic and Investment Risks: Gold, Silver, and Chinese Assets

With the Fed entering a weak dollar cycle and global liquidity expected to become abundant, the market forecasts a short-term, liquidity-driven inflationary boom phase similar to the 1920s “Coolidge Prosperity”

Gold: The De-Dollarization Anchor

Gold’s current upward trajectory is a perfect reflection of the shifting global monetary regime. It serves as the primary hedge against two simultaneous risks: systemic credit degradation in the U.S. and currency debasement resulting from inevitable QE.

  • Central Bank Accumulation: Global central banks are aggressively accumulating gold, treating it not just as a hedge, but as a transitional equivalent and a foundational asset to anchor their national currencies against anticipated dollar volatility.
  • China’s Strategic Role: China is strategically deploying gold to provide credit backing for RMB internationalization. The establishment of the Global Digital Gold Center and offshore gold vaults in Hong Kong allows overseas RMB holders to purchase gold directly, effectively creating a non-SWIFT, RMB-gold clearing mechanism. Onshore gold (mainland) remains under strict regulation, while offshore gold circulates globally. This dual-track approach positions RMB to gain credibility as the USD’s credit anchor weakens.
  • Relocation of JPM Gold Trading Division: In November, JPMorgan Chase (JPM) suddenly decided to relocate its gold trading division from the U.S. to Singapore. The short-term objective is to divert capital away from gold and back into the U.S. equity market. But at the same time, it underscores a market consensus that the future center of liquidity and pricing power for gold is structurally shifting away from Western financial hubs and toward non-USD-denominated Asian markets. This implies that the USD’s anchor on global gold transactions is weakening.
  • Forward-Looking Price Stability: Once the Quantitative Easing (QE) and the USD’s devaluation is fully priced in, the gold price will expected to move toward a new structural equilibrium (a higher base) rather than experiencing continuous, uncontrolled surges. Its primary function shifts from hyper-volatility hedging to foundational credit anchoring.

Silver: The High-Leverage Short Squeeze Game

Silver’s recent sharp price action is not primarily driven by its long-term industrial demand narrative (AI power, solar, EVs) but rather by a highly leveraged, structural market dynamic best described as a short squeeze against inadequate physical inventory.

  • The Exaggerated Leverage: Through the banking system, physical silver is transformed into derivatives and collateral, resulting in an estimated leverage expansion that may exceed 1:200 against actual physical stock.
  • The Squeeze Mechanics: Speculators aggressively take long positions and demand physical settlement. Since the paper derivatives market far outstrips the physical inventory, the market shorts (typically institutions) are unable to meet delivery obligations. The price surge is often driven by regional structural shortages—targeting low-inventory hubs (e.g., London or Shanghai) to force the shorts to lease or buy spot metal at exorbitant rates.
  • Risk Assessment: Despite the compelling long-term industrial story, silver is subject to extreme financial risk due to its hyper-leveraged structure. Any sudden, large-scale monetary tightening or a significant increase in exchange margin requirements could trigger a catastrophic deleveraging event.

Structural Tailwinds for Chinese Assets

The monetary policy divergence (USD weakness, JPY strength) and the subsequent flood of global liquidity provide a clear, structural benefit for RMB-denominated assets.

  • RMB Appreciation Bias: The combination of the Fed’s easing (devaluing the USD) and the BOJ’s tightening (stabilizing the JPY) creates a favorable environment for the RMB to appreciate against the USD.
  • Equities and Liquidity: Dollar weakness is a significant technical positive for Hong Kong stocks, signaling improving global USD liquidity. Historically, USD weakness cycles (e.g., 2003–2008) have coincided with major bull runs in A-Shares. As the Fed transitions to the weak USD phase (2023–2030), A-Shares are structurally positioned for a new strong bull cycle.

entry.title: The Dollar's Final Reckoning - Why a 2025 "Coolidge Prosperity" Precedes the Global Collapse
entry.content:
The global economy is poised at the precipice of a significant regime change, driven by the collapse of the post-1970s dollar-centric world order and the convergence of long-term economic cycles. I argue that the period beginning around 2025 will usher in a severe, yet temporary, monetary-fueled boom—a phenomenon analogous to “Coolidge Prosperity” in 1920s.

The Unraveling of Dollar Hegemony and the Debt Black Hole

The historical 16-year rhythm of the US Dollar Index (DXY), which long alternated between strong and weak phases tied to political cycles, failed after 2017.

  • Weak Dollar: 1985–1993 (Republican: Ronald Reagan & George H.W. Bush)
  • Strong Dollar: 1993–2001 (Democrat: William J. Clinton)
  • Weak Dollar: 2001–2009 (Republican: George W. Bush)
  • Strong Dollar: 2009–2016 (Democrat: Barack H. Obama)

The critical deviation occurred after 2017. Instead of the expected decline, the dollar held strong and reached an even higher peak in 2022. This failure to conform to the historical 8-year strong/weak alternation is attributed to two factors: the failure to secure the necessary capital inflow from non-US sources in the wake of the 2016 geopolitical tensions and and the unpredicted COVID-19.

This persistence of high interest rates alongside soaring debt has created a fiscal monster: the Debt Black Hole. Driven by the compounding interest on an enormous debt load, this vortex absorbs global liquidity, leading to the perverse outcome of simultaneous inflation and recession. The system is now caught in a self-devouring cycle where continued money printing fails to stimulate output and instead increases the burden on producers and consumers.

The Political Pivot: From Financial War to Fiscal Survival

The policy of “Strong Dollar/Strong Fiscal Expenditure” employed by the Biden government was essentially a strategy of financial warfare, aimed at absorbing global capital and maintaining the status quo. However, this policy proved unsustainable, leading to unsustainable US debt levels, crippling inflation, extreming wealth inequality, and profound domestic political fractures.

The political shift signaled by the rise of a Trump-led, MAGA-driven administration fundamentally changes the trajectory. Trump’s focus is on restructuring the domestic fiscal reality. This necessary pivot mandates a transition to a Weak Dollar/Weak Fiscal regime. To tame the debt black hole and ease the internal cost-of-living crisis, the US must eventually return to quantitative easing (QE) and lower interest rates.

This Weak Dollar trend echos under the 60-year Kondratiev Wave scope. The current period falls into the late decline/depression phase (estimated as 2018–?). This phase demands the resolution of massive, systemic leverage. History is unequivocal on the solution: currency devaluation.

  • 1930s: Devaluation occurred during the Great Depression.
  • 1970s: Devaluation through the abandonment of the gold standard.
  • 2025: Gold price has doubled since 2024

This pivot is the global release valve. For years, non-US economies were forced to constrain their monetary policy to defend their currencies against the strong dollar. US QE will unleash global liquidity, allowing nations worldwide to resume monetary stimulus and begin their own debt resolution through inflation.

China’s Opportunities and the New Multipolar Order

In the past decades, China has followed its own 10-year cycle of technology upgrades and capacity elimination tied to deleveraging efforts:

  • 2003: State-owned enterprise and bank bad debt stripping (AMC).
  • 2013: Supply-side structural reform (steel, paper, chemicals).
  • 2023: Tightening debt resolution for remaining old industries (e.g., Evergrande).

This 10-year cycle has historically synchronized with the long-term dollar cycles, leading to strong A-share performance during weak dollar phases:

  • Weak Dollar(91–92): Sharp Increase
  • Strong Dollar(93–01): Largely Sideways
  • Weak Dollar(03–08): Major Bull Market
  • Strong Dollar(09-22):Mostly Sideways
  • Next Weak Dollar(23–30): Anticipated Strong Bull

While the US has been preoccupied with its internal crises and external conflicts, the strong dollar period has paradoxically benefited China. The disruption and de-industrialization of US allies have effectively gifted market share to China. Having largely completed its own internal debt resolution efforts, China is uniquely positioned as the world’s largest and most complete manufacturing nation to absorb and benefit from the coming wave of global liquidity.

The current geopolitical tensions are not just about rivalry; they reflect the inevitable breakdown of the neo-liberal world order, accelerated by the US’s choice to “backstab its allies” for short-term fiscal survival. China’s strategy is not to seize global hegemony via the dollar model (a model that failed the US by abandoning manufacturing for pure monetary export), but to establish a new economic order based on RMB-Commodity/Energy transactions.

The Investment Forecast: A New Coolidge Boom

The confluence of US QE, global monetary stimulus, and China’s industrial readiness will manufacture a powerful economic rebound. This phenomenon, peaking approximately between 2025 and 2028, will be a short-term, liquidity-fueled boom. The recent AI boom is a signal of it.

Since this boom is fundamentally inflationary, the best assets are those that appreciate with rising prices, like Big Commodities (e.g., Oil, Minerals), Mining Companies, and heavy Asset Cyclical Industries.

Gold perfectly illustrates the current regime change. Central banks are using it as an equivalent value asset and a transitional medium because its value is universally recognized. Central banks are accumulating gold as a hedge against the collapse of the existing dollar-based credit system. Once the situation stabilizes (i.e., the “Coolidge Prosperity” is underway, USD devaluation is locked in, and the US debt crisis is temporarily relieved by lower rates), confidence in the economic recovery will return. By then, major central banks will stop aggressively buying gold, and the price will naturally settle down. Paradoxically, if a true recession were to break out, gold might be sold off as liquidity is needed.

This period of exuberance, while potentially very profitable, is temporary. It will conclude with a subsequent deep downturn (2028–2032), possibly triggered by a spike in oil prices engineered by US-aligned producers after the Russia-Ukraine conflict concludes, as the US seeks to restore dollar credibility after its devaluation.

U.S. Market: Rate Cut, Trade Deal, and Hawkish Tilt

On Wednesday, the Fed followed through with another 0.25% rate cut and announced it would end its balance sheet reduction (Quantitative Tightening) on December 1st. While these moves were generally expected, Fed Chair Powell emphasized that a decision on whether to cut rates again in December remains unsettled, noting internal divisions within the Fed. The market interpreted this message as slightly hawkish, leading to a downward adjustment in future rate cut expectations. This pushed U.S. Treasury yields up, and bond prices down.

Despite this downward adjustment in future rate cut expectations, two major factors propelled the stock market:

  • Trade Deal Progress: A meeting between the U.S. and Chinese presidents resulted in a trade agreement that, at the very least, prevented an escalation of the trade war, pushing market sentiment toward optimism.
  • Strong Earnings: As of this week, about two-thirds of S&P 500 companies had released Q3 earnings, with over 80% beating expectations. Large technology stocks were particularly strong, with Nvidia becoming the first company to temporarily breach the $5 trillion valuation mark (Is this a bubble or a boost? Time will tell). In contrast, small-cap stocks struggled for gains.

Europe & Japan: Diverging Central Bank and Political Impacts

The ECB maintained its policy rate and stressed that its future policy path remains data-dependent, offering little new guidance. Consequently,

  • European bond markets, particularly German bonds, largely tracked the U.S. trend, with yields rising slightly.
  • French bonds, still recovering from a recent sharp sell-off, saw a small gain this week.
  • The UK market was unique. The Prime Minister hinted in Parliament at the possibility of raising taxes to fill the fiscal hole. This supported UK bond prices but simultaneously raised concerns about the UK economy, leading the pound (GBP) to fall sharply. The depreciation of the pound, in turn, boosted UK stocks, making the UK market a clear outperformer compared to Germany and France.
    • Why raising taxes boost bond price and weaken GBP?
      • When the government signals fiscal consolidation (like a tax hike), it suggests that future borrowing needs will be reduced. That means the government will issue fewer new bonds (Gilts) than previously expected. A reduction in the future supply of debt puts upward pressure on bond prices.
      • On the other hand, higher taxes reduce disposable income for consumers and profits for businesses, leading to less spending, investment, and hiring. It will also accelerate the probability of lower interest rates from the Bank of England (BoE), which can cause a capital outflow. Thus the GBP will depreciate.

In Japan, the BOJ once again held steady and indicated it wanted to see a clear trend of rising wages next year before considering a rate hike. This weakened market expectations for a December rate hike, supporting the stock rally.

In addition, the Takaichi Trade accelerates this rally. Strong support for the new cabinet and market expectations that Japanese companies would increase investment in the U.S. following Trump’s visit drove a significant surge in Japanese stocks. The massive flow of capital into stocks somewhat offset the boost to bonds from weakened rate hike fears, resulting in Japanese bond prices seeing little change for the week.

entry.title: Will the Recent Gold Rally Last Long?
entry.content:
Gold has been on an impressive run, with prices more than doubling from $1,429 per ounce in November 2022 to $3,700 per ounce by today, a 30% compound annual growth rate. This surge has captured a lot of attention, and for good reason. But with gold breaking new highs, many investors are asking a crucial question: What is the next for gold?

To understand the risks, we can look to two recent analyses: a detailed historical review from the World Gold Council (WGC) and an article from D.E. Shaw.

The World Gold Council’s Historical View

The World Gold Council’s report on the bear case for gold analyzes five major pullbacks in its price since the 1971 Bretton Woods collapse. These historical declines were generally driven by three main factors: rising opportunity costs, cooling risks and uncertainty, and structural supply changes.

Here is a summary of each pullback:

  • 1st Bear Run (1974-1976): The Establish of Petrodollar
    The anchor of dollar changed from gold to oil, which strengthened the dollar again and as a result, gold price pullbacked.
  • 2nd & 3rd Bear Run (1980-1982 & 1983-1985): Hike Rates to Fight Inflation
    Although the report separates two pullbacks, I personally believe these two were both the result of then-Fed Chair Paul Volcker rates hiking for inflation cool down. The sharp rise in real interest rates caused the dollar to strengthen
  • 4th Bear Run (1987-1999): Formation of Unipolar Hegemony
    This was the longest bear run in history. The collapse of the Soviet Union marked the end of Cold War, which significantly reduced geopolitical risk. Dollar become the only worldwide currency and all central banks generally believed that gold has lost its monetary properties and started to sell over the years.
  • 5th Bear Run (2011-2015): Rising Real Interest Rate
    After the Fed ended its quantitative easing program, the real yield rose and dollar became strengthed.

It is obvious that the underlying reason for a pullback is the stengthen of dollar, either confidence level (Petrodollar, Unipolar Hegemony) or fundamental level (increase in real interest rate, decrease in inflation, economic strength)

This report also mentioned the near-term and long-term risk for gold price weakness.

D.E. Shaw’s Portfolio Optimization Aspect of Gold

D.E. Shaw tackles the issue from a different angle, addressing the problem of valuing gold. Unlike stocks or bonds, which have future cash flows, gold is a non-productive store of value (NPSOV). This makes it impossible to price using traditional methods like discounted cash flow.

Instead, D.E. Shaw proposes a model based on gold’s relationship with other assets and use optimizer to illustrate the ideal time to add gold to a portfolio.

  1. In a positive stock-bond correlation environment, the potential portfolio utility of gold increases, even if our forecast for gold remains unchanged.
  2. A strong expectation of high inflation and a looming stock market crash

These were further comfirmed by optimizer for portfolio allocation. Specifically, the more exposed the portfolio is to risks like a positive stock-bond correlation, equity crashes, or inflation shocks, the more value the optimizer assigns to gold’s diversification benefits.

Synthesis: Why a Bear Case is Unlikely Now

Combining the insights from both reports, a powerful picture emerges. The factors that have historically driven gold into a bear market—a strong U.S. dollar and cooling geopolitical risks—are not currently present.

The U.S. economy faces a unique situation where both “weak dollar” and “de-dollarization” forces are active. “Weak dollar” is a deliberate action by the U.S. to devalue its currency to stimulate a soft economy and manufacturing. “De-dollarization” is a trend among other countries to reduce their reliance on the dollar for trade, often due to concerns over its use as a tool for sanctions. When both the producer of the dollar (the U.S.) and its major consumers (other export-heavy nations) are moving away from the currency, the result is a powerful “double kill” that prevents the dollar from fundamentally strengthening.

Therefore, given the current macro environment, the historical conditions for a gold bear run simply do not exist. While short-term pullbacks are always possible, the core factors that have fueled gold’s bull run—high geopolitical risk, a weak dollar, and fears of inflation—remain firmly in place.

Some Personal Thoughts

The traditional framework for gold analysis depends on real interest rate + overall returns of other asset classes.

  • The lower real interest rate, the higher gold price.
    • Econ 101 tells us the real interest rate = norminal interest rate - inflation. It’s very easy to get the relationship between inflation and gold price.
    • In the real market, traders also consider expectation, ie. real interest rate = (realized norminal interest rate + expected norminal interest rate) - (realized inflation + expected inflation). That makes things a bit complex.
  • The higher other asset classes returns, the lower gold price

But since 2022, the framework no longer holds. The main reason is that we have a lower boundery for real interest rate. We cannot go below 0 for too long. However, the gold has no up ceiling.

Now, the new logic behind the all-time high gold price is the global debt and credit, especially US government credit problem and debt monetization. There are only two ways to alleviate the current crisis.

  1. War
  2. Technological progress + reshoring of high-value-added manufacturing
    • the problem is reshoring of manufacturing impacts China’s interests and unavoidablely, this can cause the conflict between these two big countries.

Thus, as long as the credit problem is not solved, the gold price won’t come down.

On Wednesday, the Federal Reserve cut interest rates by 0.25%, the first cut in nine months and a move that was in line with market expectations. The dot plot, which forecasts the future path of interest rates, showed the potential for two more cuts by the end of the year.

Fed Chair Powell described this as a “risk management” cut, suggesting that although economic data hadn’t significantly deteriorated and inflation remained a concern, the job market seemed to be weakening. Historically, rate-cutting cycles that begin before a full-blown economic downturn are often favorable for stocks. This sentiment, combined with other positive news like Nvidia’s investment in Intel, fueled an optimistic mood. As a result, the S&P 500, Nasdaq, and Dow Jones all hit new record highs.

In contrast to the stock market, the bond market was more conservative. Since the Fed’s decision—both the size of the cut and the future forecast—didn’t exceed market expectations, and because weekly retail and employment data showed some improvement, U.S. Treasury yields rose slightly, causing bond prices to dip.

  • Why does bond price go down after the interest rate cut?
    • It is often called ‘buy the rumor, sell the news’. The market has already anticipate for almost 100% chance that the Fed will cut the rate.     • When the Fed delivered exactly what was expected, there was no new information to cause a further rally. Instead, some traders likely “sold the news,” locking in profits from the anticipated rate cut.
    • The improving economic data contradicted the recession fears that had been building
      • Retail Sales: The data showed that retail spending was improving, indicating that consumer demand remained resilient
      • Unemployment Claims: The number of new unemployment claims fell significantly for the week, pushing back against recent concerns of a rapid labor market deterioration

    • Topix Index covers all domestic stocks listed on the Tokyo Stock Exchange with market capitalization weight. Each individual stock influence is capped at 10%.

Higher borrowing costs for companies can cut into their profits and slow down expansion plans. For consumers, higher interest rates on mortgages, auto loans, and other credit can dampen spending. Thus the whole economy will slow down.
      2. Impact on Valuation: Higher interest rates also make stocks less attractive to investors. A higher discount rate means a lower present value for the stock, putting downward pressure on stock prices.
      3. Reduced Investor Confidence: A new element of political and economic uncertainty is introduced. This “uncertainty tax” can cause businesses to delay investment and consumers to become more cautious, both of which can lead to a slowing economy. Such a pessimistic outlook makes investors more risk-averse, prompting a flight from stocks into safer assets.

However, the trend was dramatically reversed from Wednesday to Friday with a series of three weak U.S. employment reports. The data showed a decline in job openings, lower-than-expected payroll growth, and an increase in unemployment claims. The deteriorating employment picture intensified market expectations for a Federal Reserve rate cut. The market is now highly confident of a rate cut in September, with some even anticipating an aggressive 0.5% reduction. This concern leads to

  • Treasury yields are pushed down
    • reasons:
      1. the Fed Fund rate is the major impact of the treasury yield, especially the short term.
  • The impact on stocks was more mixed. On one hand, rate cut expectations served as a catalyst, but on the other, the consecutive weak employment reports fueled fears of an economic recession. Amid this push and pull, U.S. stocks ended the week slightly higher.
    • A major driver for the tech sector was Google’s legal victory in an antitrust case, which prevented its Chrome browser business from being broken up. This win was a “win-win” for both Google and Apple, securing a key business for Google and protecting its lucrative deal to be the default search engine on Apple devices. The news boosted both companies’ share prices and propelled the Nasdaq index.

Europe & Japan: Political and Economic Tensions

Like the U.S., European markets were initially weighed down by fiscal worries, including a potential no-confidence vote in the French government and the UK’s challenging budget discussions. However, they were eventually lifted by the positive spillover from the U.S. bond and stock rallies.

Both the Japanese bond and stock markets ended the week higher.

  • Bond: Calls for an early leadership election within the Liberal Democratic Party to oust fiscally conservative Prime Minister Ishiba raised concerns about potential fiscal expansion. This put downward pressure on Japanese bonds, but the stronger influence of rising U.S. bond prices ultimately led to a small gain.
    • Why concerns about potential fiscal expansion can put downward pressure on Japanese bond prices
      1. Suppy & Demand: Fiscal expansion comes alone with issuing new government bonds. This increase in the supply of bonds in the market can overwhelm demand, causing bond prices to fall.
      2. Inflationary Expectations: Significant fiscal expansion can be seen as inflationary. By injecting more money into the economy, it can lead to higher prices. Bondholders are particularly sensitive to inflation because it erodes the future purchasing power of their fixed interest payments. To compensate for this risk, investors will sell their existing bonds, driving down prices and pushing up yields.
  • Stocks: Japanese stocks were boosted by the rally in U.S. tech stocks and the finalization of a U.S. tariff on Japan at a moderate 15%, which was less severe than the market had initially feared.
    • Why the finalization of a U.S. tariff on Japan at a moderate 15% boosted Japanese stocks
      1. Removal of Uncertainty: Markets dislike uncertainty. The finalization of a rate, even a punitive one, allows businesses to plan and adjust. The absence of this major unknown is a positive for market stability and investor confidence. Plus, the initial fears of the possibility of a much higher tarrif rate, possibly as high as 25% or more, or a broader range of products being targeted, creates a positive surprise comparing to this moderate 15%.
      2. Managed Economic Impact: A 15% tariff, while not ideal, is a manageable headwind for many Japanese export-oriented companies. They can potentially absorb some of the cost, pass a portion on to consumers, or adjust their supply chains to mitigate the impact. A higher tariff could have been a catastrophic shock, but a moderate one is a challenge that can be overcome, which reassures investors about the profitability and stability of Japanese corporations.

Commodities: Geopolitical and Policy Influences

The expectation of a rate cut lowered the opportunity cost of holding gold, while mounting fears of a recession increased demand for safe-haven assets. These two factors combined to drive a significant increase in gold prices.

Oil prices, on the other hand, fell. The market is anticipating that OPEC may decide to increase production at its September 7th ministerial meeting, while recession fears have lowered demand expectations. The combination of increased supply and decreased demand put strong downward pressure on oil prices.

entry.title: The Structure of FOMC and Who Are Trump's People
entry.content:
The Fed’s primary monetary policy-making body, the Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC), has 12 voting members. Of these, seven seats are permanently held by the seven members of the Board of Governors. The remaining five seats rotate among the presidents of the 12 regional Federal Reserve banks.

A governor’s term is an extensive 14 years, with a new seat expiring every two years. This staggered system ensures a degree of policy continuity. Under this design, a president can, in theory, appoint at least two governors during a single term, allowing them to shape the Fed’s long-term policy direction.

So, who on the current Board of Governors can be considered “Trump’s people?”

During his first term, Trump appointed two governors: Michelle Bowman and Christopher Waller. Both of them voted in favor of a rate cut at the July meeting. However, it’s clear that the current Fed, led by Chairman Jerome Powell (also a Trump appointee in 2018), has not fully aligned with Trump’s aggressive push for rapid rate cuts to stimulate the economy and ease the government’s interest burden.

It’s precisely this lack of full alignment that has made Trump eager to exert greater influence through new appointments.

Based on the staggered term schedule, Trump has two theoretical opportunities to appoint new governors during his second term:

  • The first opportunity is in January 2026.
  • The second is when Powell’s term as a governor expires in 2028.

However, waiting until 2028 is not an ideal option if he wants to see immediate policy changes. This timeline explains his recent urgency to find additional opportunities to place his own people on the board and steer the Fed toward his desired course.

This put pressure on the long end of the yield curve. As a result, U.S. bonds saw overall price increases, but the yield curve became steeper.

Other news included Friday’s PCE data, which largely met expectations and had little impact on rate cut forecasts. The auctions for 2, 5, and 7-year Treasury notes also showed relatively solid demand.

The French no-confidence vote, triggered by a budget impasse, created the risk of the Bayrou government collapsing. The market, fearing political chaos and a potential fiscal crisis, put selling pressure on both French bonds and stocks, which in turn dragged down the broader European market. Money fleeing France for safer havens caused the yield spread between German and French bonds to widen. Gold prices also moved higher, largely benefiting from the Fed controversy. The firing of the governor strengthened expectations for a rate cut, increased long-term inflation risk, and damaged the Fed’s independence. All three of these factors served to push gold prices higher.

US Markets: The Anticipation and Reveal

For the past few weeks, a prevailing market narrative has been the expectation of a Fed rate cut in September. This was fueled by a combination of weakening U.S. economic data and the realization that inflation from tariffs wasn’t as high as initially feared. However, this was just market speculation. The real validation had to come from the Fed itself.

Thus from Monday to Thursday, the market was in a state of cautious observation. The S&P 500, having seen significant gains recently, faced selling pressure and registered four consecutive days of small declines.

On Friday, however, Powell’s speech revealed the Fed’s stance. He stated that the current policy rate is tight and that employment-related risks are significant, making a policy adjustment a “reasonable option.” While the wording was cautious, the market immediately caught the signal of a coming rate cut. In response, U.S. Treasury yields fell, and bond prices rose.

The mood in the U.S. stock market returned to optimism, and markets put the odds of a September cut at 90%. All previous downward trend sharply reversed on Friday. Most major U.S. indices saw gains, with the Nasdaq being the only exception. Despite a strong Friday rebound, it still closed slightly down for the week after its earlier sharp declines.

European & Japanese Markets: Divergent Paths

European markets, in addition to being affected by the Fed’s rate cut signals, also closely watched developments in the Ukraine-Russia situation. On Monday, European and Ukrainian leaders met with Donald Trump, and the market’s hope for a swift resolution to the conflict helped boost European stocks. However, after several weeks of continuous gains, the stock markets in Germany and France showed some fatigue and struggled to rise further.

The anticipated de-escalation of the conflict should have, in theory, reduced safe-haven demand and pushed European bond prices lower. However, the market adopted a wait-and-see approach, so the downward pressure on bonds was limited. Instead, the rally in U.S. bonds had a more pronounced effect, pulling European bonds higher. The notable exception was the UK, where higher-than-expected CPI data reduced expectations of a Bank of England rate cut, causing UK bonds to underperform their German and French counterparts.

n Japan, both government bonds and stocks saw declines, showing a trend opposite to that of Europe. This was partly due to the time difference—the Fed’s signal came too late to fully impact the Japanese market. Another key factor was internal: after hitting a record high the previous week, the Japanese stock market faced significant selling pressure. This, combined with the decline in U.S. tech stocks, led to a weekly drop. The decline in Japanese government bonds primarily reflected market caution about fiscal expansion, which was evident in weak demand during this week’s bond auctions and the Bank of Japan’s bond purchase operations.

Commodities: Riding the Wave

The Fed’s rate cut signal, along with general market optimism, boosted demand expectations and contributed to a small increase in oil prices.

Gold also saw a modest rise, mainly influenced by U.S. Treasury yields. Since bond yields reflect the opportunity cost of holding gold, falling U.S. Treasury yields make gold relatively more attractive, thus pushing its price higher.

As the August 1st deadline approached, President Trump signed a new tariff order on July 31st, further heightening market anxiety and putting downward pressure on US stocks.

Fed Reserve and Economic Data

On Wednesday, the Fed kept interest rates unchanged (as expected), but the Fed Chair downplayed expectations for a September rate cut during the press conference. This hit the stock market and also put downward pressure on bond prices (pushing yields up).

However, on Friday, both the Non-Farm Payroll (NFP) and PMI data came in weaker than expected. Meanwile, the NFP of May and June were revised down about 90%, way larger than normal. This led the market to believe the Fed would have to restart rate cuts sooner to counter the risk of an economic recession.

This reversal in expectations ultimately led to US bond yields falling (prices rising). At the same time, concerns about a recession intensified selling pressure on stocks, causing the US market to pull back significantly from its highs.

This also impact the Europe stock and bond market. Both European bond yields and stocks trended lower on Friday.

Japanese Market

On Thursday, the Bank of Japan (BoJ) announced that it would not raise interest rates for now and raised its inflation forecast for this year and next.

Governor Kazuo Ueda’s comments were also conservative. This pushed Japanese government bond yields slightly lower (prices rose slightly). He also mentioned that the current yen Exchange Rates has not deviated significantly from the Bank of Japan’s expectations and will not have a significant impact on the price outlook. This was interpreted by the market as the BoJ tolerating a weaker yen, which triggered a yen sell-off.

In theory, no rate hike and a weaker yen are positive for Japanese stocks. However, two stronger factors dominated: profit-taking pressure after last week’s major rally and the drag from falling US stocks. Therefore, Japanese stocks ended the week lower.

Gold

Prices increased slightly, mainly influenced by US Treasury yields. Holding gold does not generate interest, so government bond yields represent the opportunity cost of holding gold. Thus, the decline in US Treasury yields this week lowered the opportunity cost of investing in gold, pushing its price higher.

entry.title: Weekly Global Market Summary 7/27/2025
entry.content:
This week’s market logic is quite clear, though the details can get a bit complex. Let’s break it down.

Japan Election Upset and the Bond Market Paradox

The week’s biggest story started in Japan. Over the weekend, the ruling coalition led by Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba suffered a major defeat in the upper house election, losing its majority. This turns the Ishiba cabinet into a minority government, sparking media speculation that the Prime Minister might resign.

From a market perspective, this created a complex reaction to Japanese Government Bonds (JGBs):

  • Pre-Election Jitters: Markets had already anticipated an imminent opposition victory. Because the opposition parties generally advocate for expansionary fiscal policy, investors grew concerned about Japan’s deficit and the potential for an over-issuance of government bonds. This led to a sell-off in JGBs starting from early this month.
  • Post-Election Reversal: While the ruling coalition lost, the defeat wasn’t as severe as many had feared. This eased concerns about runaway fiscal spending, which in turn reduced the pressure to sell JGBs.
  • Political Risk: At the same time, the prospect of a minority government and a potential prime minister resignation increased political uncertainty. This boosted safe-haven demand, creating buying pressure for JGBs.

Based on these factors, one would expect JGB prices to rise. So why did they fall (JP10y 1.532% -> 1.603%)?

The Game Changer: The US-Japan Trade Agreement

The answer lies in the week’s other major news story. On the evening of July 22nd, President Trump announced that the US and Japan had reached a trade agreement. Key terms include a $550 billion investment by Japan in the United States and a reduction of US tariffs on Japanese goods to 15%.

This news injected a massive dose of optimism into the market:

  • Japanese and US Stocks Soared: Japanese stocks, particularly in the auto sector, surged on the news. This optimism spread to the US, where strong earnings reports (with over 80% of companies beating profit expectations) also helped push the S&P 500 and Nasdaq to new record highs.
  • Safe-Haven Demand Faded: The positive sentiment caused capital to flow from the safety of bonds into equities. For Japan, the stable trade environment also increased the likelihood that the Bank of Japan could consider restarting interest rate hikes in the future. This created immense downward pressure on Japanese bonds, ultimately overwhelming the upward push from the election results.

Consequently, JGB yields rose significantly (ie. prices fell).

US Treasuries and The Fed

On Thursday, President Trump visited the Federal Reserve in Washington, D.C., to review building renovations. He tried to use the $2 billion renovation costs to ramp up political pressure on Chairman Jerome Powell to lower the benchmark interest rate. This reversed the logic from the previous week, causing the US Treasury yield curve to flatten, as long-term yields fell.

A Look at Europe

  • ECB: The European Central Bank held interest rates steady at 2% on Thursday, pausing its year-long policy easing cycle and adopting a “wait-and-see” approach on future rate cuts. This was in line with expectations and had little market impact.
  • Bonds: Amid the global optimism, German and French bond spreads tightened. In the UK, however, weak retail sales data and the Chancellor’s commitment to fiscal control helped push UK government bonds slightly higher.
  • Stocks: UK stocks rose, driven primarily by corporate earnings. German and French stocks remained largely unchanged as investors await progress on US-EU trade negotiations.

Dollar and Commodities

  • US Dollar: Since President Trump’s tariff wars had the effect of strengthening the dollar. A trade agreement, therefore, has the opposite effect. The de-escalation of trade tensions pushed the US dollar lower(-0.79(-0.8%)).
  • Gold: A weaker dollar is typically bullish for gold. However, the dominant force this week was market optimism, which reduces demand for safe-haven assets. As a result, gold finished the week slightly down (-$12.61(-0.38%)).
  • Oil: While market optimism provided a tailwind for oil prices, supply-side news created stronger headwinds. Reports indicated that OPEC+ will decide to continue production at its upcoming meeting, the US eased restrictions on Venezuelan oil, and Chinese economic data raised concerns about future energy demand. The downward pressure from supply ultimately won out, and oil prices fell modestly (-0.89(-1.35%)).
